text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Thursday.
- Traffic experts from Croatia and Bosnia will ask European Union to grant them seven road and railway corridors including those to Belgrade, Budapest and Albania.
- Prime minister Zlatko Matesa says demining of the last Serb enclave in eastern Slavonia well under way. Slavonska banka soon to open its branches there as a step towards reintegration.
- Central bank's interest rate fell to eight percent in August from 32 percent in May as its hard currency reserves reached $2.34 million.
- EBRD as a European bank is still the biggest foreign investor in Croatia, but its general manager for eastern Europe Peter Bod says peace will draw other investors.
- Two more private secondary schools opening in Zagreb this fall in addition to six that already exist.
- Vital railway route between Croatian port Ploce and Sarajevo to become operational in January following an agreement signed between Croatian and Bosnian railway companies.

- Government proposes new law on war veterans envisaging more advantages for all cathegories of invalids. State to provide them with some 4,670 new flats by the end of the year. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
